Even if you've never played turn-based games before (like myself), give this one a shot, you'll enjoy yourself far more than you'd expect during combat. Oh and a large part of the gameplay is exploring and talking to people, which Larian have done quite well.

Apropos exploring and talking... The world you'll find yourself exploring is very detailed and always a pleasure to look upon. The only reason you might not find hyper detailed props and textures everywhere you look, is that otherwise your graphics card might commit sepukku. The characters and people you meet throughout your adventure are all brought to life by very good character designs and phenomenal voice actors.

Now to the story, its good, really good. Is it a magnum opus of a story? Nyeh... no not really, is it still good? Absolutely. 
What they've done quite good as well are the companions you're travelling with. Even though you won't get to shank all of them in one playthrough, the core companions all have their own storylines which you can follow. These are - like most of this game - very well made, though some of them have greater impact on the main story than others.
Even though I've just finished my first playthrough, I'll replay it, because there are just so many possible approaches to encounters, choices, and that isn't even including the character creator.

Yeah, the character creator. It's complex and gives you a lot of choices as to who you are, what class you play, what your origin is, what spells or sub-classes you use - And then you haven't even changed to look of your character!

Sooo... yeah, play it.
You'll have fun.

As one of the open/ closed beta players, I am extremely disappointed in the what came to be the full release. I was so excited for the game to be completed. I put hours and hours into the prerelease game, and then when it was full released, I bolted through the first act, the second act wasn't appealing, so I bolted through that too. I got to the third act thinking there would be MUCH more content, because it had to be right? Surely after everyone experienced the full content of act 1 in early games, and having to drag your feet through the second act in turn based actions, surely there would be much more content! To me it felt like there'd be a 4th act, then suddenly there's this quick pivot and you're at the end of the game. It was a terrible feeling. After so much hype and hope building up, the only thought I had at the end of the game was 'really? This is it? I spent so much time playing in beta as a guinea pig, constantly having to remake a character, and this is all that I had to look forward too?!'

I recommend the game to people of course, but i also tell them to take their time in ACT 1, because the game is extremely short after it.

I have a love/hate relationship with this game.  The characters/voice actors are excellent, best I've ever experienced.  The story seems decent, but I've only experienced up to the end of Act 1.  And here lies the problem: I absolutely HATE the combat.  

Combat encounters take forever, and I always feel outnumbered and under-powered.  I've tried about a dozen different builds, a multitude of strategies, but nothing feels powerful.  Things feel a tiny bit better after you get to level 5, but it's a slog up to that point.  The game AI is very unfair.  Enemy will always outnumber you, will have access to more and better spells, and rarely misses.  And there is no excuse for the idiotic camera control in a game with this price tag. 

In a word, frustrating.  If you're not experienced in D&D rules, you should probably skip this one.

I love this game, and would say this is worth every cent of the 60 euros and even more. With the added mod manager this game allows for even more creativity and freedom, which was already an extraordinary amount. Excellent replay value! I have over 200 hours as of writing this review and I still find new things constantly. If you do not care for playing through a story line or don't care for roleplay, I can imagine this game could be a bit lacking. But it still offers a fun challenge for people who like complicated and strategic combat, and exploration. DnD mechanics are integrated into the game very well, in my not so expert opinion, and it helped me understand the mechanic of DnD better. 

And also, because of course we cannot ignore it, the romance is a lot of fun. I also believe, contrary to what other seem to complain about, that the romance is not forced onto you or obnoxious. Once you reject a character they won't pursue you and you still get to have their emotional story through a platonic POV. 

All in all, recommend this game a 100% and I want to thank Larian for bringing out my obsession of the past months!

The journey that Baldur's Gate 3 has within is astonishing. Adapting all D'n'D mechanics to a video game is an incredible quest on its own, that Larian were managed to accomplish. The game gets you for a long time. Going through Act 2 ending, i already have ideas for the next walkthrough, which i'm sure i will start right after final credits. The world and the story is in every object and sound. It's all about the nature, the architecture, the environment, that i can't help myself but taking a closer look at. Not just main characters have astonishing level of details about their appearance, behavior and stories, NPSs also do. You gain bonds with every character, each in a different way.

The best part for me is, there is no way to play the game wrong. Your decisions, or not making them at all, can be represented in a different combinations of verbal interactions and doings. There is literally a numerous ways to put your own idea in all of the happening events. 

The game is a great deal of work, looking forward to the next Larian's project in the future. Big thanks to the developing team <3

My Intro To DND = rating: 8.75/10 - A fantastic game that is not without its flaws in the final act. Spoilers below.

Pros:
- Beautiful graphics that are seamless between gameplay and cutscenes.
- My first introduction to DnD and its is really well presented and fun to play. love the dice rolls, lots of ways to play.
- Meaningfull dialogue choices and an intriguing plot
- well fleshed out characters and world.
- Great turn based combat.
- A slow but good start with Act 1
- Act 2 is the game at its height, would of been 10/10 if we stopped here and got rid of some BG city references obviously.
- Thorm is a pretty good villain. 


The negatives are long and more detailed to showcase why such a great game fell a point and a bit for me.
Negatives:
- The game generally falls apart around act 3 in terms of bugs and writing quality. Characters would constantly forget what i did (like wyll begging me to save his father from the prison even tho he is in camp with us and they talked, the printing press pixie knowing then not knowing who i am etc).
- Characters constantly stop following you if you jump somewhere, even if they can follow.
- The city is underwhelming despite being overwhelming with nothing npcs.
- The gather your allies quest mattered a lot less than i thought. All of your hard work is tied down to a friendly npc to help fight in the final area, they get no or minimal send offs after the fight which is laughable in a game like this, if you aren't part of the main crew, you dont affect the ending. Not even a bare minimum slideshow like Fallout NV. (this brings it from 9/10 to 8.75, very empty feeling ending).
- Orsin may just be the lamest thing ever along with her self cloak every turn, unstoppable, minions. They are some of the most annoying enemies in gaming. Nothing worse than knowing orsin is copying someone only to have you character look like a fool and gasp for the 5th time. One note evil characters can be good, but not like this in this late of a role. Couldnt tell you much about gortash, bro sits in his office and they should of showed more of what his evil rule is like as the act continues.
- The final fight is enemy spam which only made gales bomb seem like a better option every turn.
- My ending just stopped when karlach went to avernus with wyl, music played as we were forced to stare at her up close for 7 minutes before i had to reboot the game to pre boss fight... so gale option it was.
